column4: Ubuntu networking is giving me a lot of problems in my laptop. I need to switch between LANS at my work, and the wireless at my home. I know how to use the network-admin dialog. But it screws up so often. I get socioflags error, sometimes dns resolution doesn't work. And sometimes networking just doesn't work without any reasons.
network-manager doesn't do it automatically for you?
It doesn't do anything for me. I know how to set the gateway, ip, dns and I do it manually. And it works quite often. But it breaks down too often.
So network-manager doesn't "Just Work" for you at all?
are you using dhcp ?
Yes! No I use static ips.
I have deleted everything from the network manager.
And will key in my home and work space again.
Umm.. OK.
But it breaks down so often. Especially at work when I switch between different switches. It just acts up.
did you do this because you hate n-m, or because you prefer to do things this way?
Did what? I use the n-m to manually key in everything. Properly. And then it starts working.
Then when I go to another place at my work and use that LAN or switch between wireless or something. It just refuses to start
no, network-manager is the bit that doesn't require manual config
Oh. I am not aware. But I am ok with manually doing it to get it working.
sounds like you are choosing manual - if you use dhcp that isn't necessary
Both my home and network don't have dhcp.
Hmmm - by choice?
I know the subnets, the gateway, the dns, the wpa keys. I put in everything at the proper place. And for no reason it refuses to work when I switch lan wires
my work doesn't have dhcp because of the network admin.
And I don't need a dhcp at my home
Can you tell me how to clear everything associated with my network and start from scratch?
I think n-m gets confused by static configs and falls over
Like how would a plain ubuntu install be?
Can I just not have the network manager? I am ready to key in everything in the network-admin and toggle it myself
If you know you only ever use static Ips I would simply uninstall network-manager
I don't want the 'just work' facility
Are you sure it is causing all these problems?
Yes, you can uninstall n-m
No - I'm not there to troubleshoot :) But removing it would tell you
When I say System>Network what is that utility called?
And how do i start network-manager?
Umm - for troubleshooting purpose, uninstall network-manager-gnome and network-manager, see if that helps. If not then the problem is elsewhere, right?
You can put it back if that makes no difference
what is the utility in system>network called?
It is through that that I key in all the info.
Can I just ask the network manager to not take initiative?
netwrk-admin I think
Can you tell me how to wipe all network configs and start afresh?
network-admin
Maybe the network manager can be tamed?
Just uninstall it and see what happens!
It's part of the troubleshooting
It's reversible
But there are no white and blacks, just right now my laptop started working when I re-started the wireless through dhcp.
Last repetition - remove n-m. If that works, great. If not, put it back and try again
ok ok. Even you are stuck on that.
I'm not stuck. I'm suggesting a troubleshooting procedure
Can you tell me how to search the ubuntu wiki and community docs properly? I never get results.
I never saw the n-m gui though. Where does it lie?
Usually all you see is the applet icon in the notification area
amenado: you know once I had removed that interfaces file and then it took 30 minutes everytime to start my laptop. Then ikonia suggested putting in some "lo" back in that file and it became well.
Oh yes. Loopback it was.
correct - you only need the loopback in that file
But that is only for using n-m - if you want manual config only, it's better to remove n-m
Can I use n-m if I need to manually put my ip, gateway, dns, wpa keys all different for different networks?
Theoretically yes. In fact the Debian and Ubuntu versions of n-m don't like that. I think the hardy version might have fixed the conflict, but I don't know that for sure
Alright I will junk it. But the network-admin will remain perfectly usable won't it?
yes, it's separate
Both are gone. Do I need to restart? I deleted all the 'locations' in the network-admin. Tell me which other config files to clear.
Umm - you din't uninstall network-admin, did you?
No just network-manager and *-gnome.
OK
It now says networkManager applet could not find the required resources it cannot continue.
So now you should be able to manually config
of course :) You uninstalled it Try running /etc/init.d/dbus restart
You should be able to use network-admin to make your settings now without conflicts
Is there a way to remove the network-admin configured optons?
... umm, obviously you can remove them either from the GUI or by editing /etc/network/interfaces
After clearing the interface file, restarting dbus and restarting networking still the internet works!
Shouldn't it let me manually key in stuff before working?
Are you *sure* you have no dhcp server on your network?
alternatively, the fact that it is working means that your manual config is correct.
in which case you don't need to re-enter it
